title: Will the closing price of Brent crude oil be higher than $70.00 per barrel on 30 December 2021?
preds: If yes, my earlier forecasts were an over-reliance on the overall base rate, leaving out better resolution of the short-term trends.
over $79 today and heading up the last few trading days
The price is continuing to increase. I believe my previous end of year Rally theory was sound and so I will go all in.

With 8 days remaining and current price being almost 10% above 70, it’s highly unlikely to not end above 70 on 31/12.

The current price of Brent crude oil is $76.19. I believe that low US inventories will prevent that price from decreasing below $70 over the next week. However, I recognize that the omicron strain may affect the price action. Therefore, I'll place this forecast at 95% to represent my very strong belief that the price of oil will not dip below $70, as well as my concession that omicron or some other unknown-unknown may potentially result in the price of oil decreasing.
sitting at $71 today...  this was a great benchmark to chose at $70.  Will likely remain very close to that.

Supply chain problems and the diversion of strategic reserves to off shore customers will continue to put pressures on crude prices. The large increase in Holiday travel this year will be another influence.
*At this point,* I can't fathom probabilities over 75%. I can sympathize with those between 35% and 75%.
I am becoming more confident of the need to look beyond the current price. I suspect that we are in for a pretty significant omicron shock to the markets in the next 2 weeks.

Lockdown looming in several European countries, e.g. the Netherlands beginning soon until 17 Jan '22.
Holiday travel is going to be reduced to a minimum across the continent.
I really don't enjoy these yes/no questions where there is a good chance that it will finish really close to the boundary. I probably won't do any more of them. I like the WTI question better

Trading ~$75/barrel currently, a correction like this would most likely be due to Omicron shutting down the Nation again and inventories not being sold because commercial customers are no longer on the road and are stuck back at home in isolation. This kind of shutdown is unlikely to happen during the Holidays because of the political posturing required, thus I find it likely that Crude Oil will remain higher than $70.00/barrel on 30 Dec 21. And actually, I think there is a higher chance that prices would rise to $79/barrel, within the same timeframe, due to increased demand by both commercial and final lap shipping companies.
Brent went to $75 today, and time is running out.  Upping the odds.

The price of Brent crude fell rapidly after the news of Omicron.  So it seems the answer to this question depends as much on the virulence of Omicron as on the decisions of OPEC+.  Expectations regarding both supply and demand determine the price. Recent reports say Omicron is spreading twice as fast in South Africa as Delta.  See https://www.nytimes.com/2021/12/03/health/coronavirus-omicron-vaccines-contagiousness.html.  The deadliness of Omicron is still open to debate, but some anecdotal evidence suggests it is less deadly.  If it is more transmissible but less deadly than Delta it could actually be a good thing.  See https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2021/12/how-bad-omicron-variant/620870/. Before the end of December I expect there will be more clarity regarding the severity of disease caused by Omicron.  That news will probably move the price of Brent, but in which direction.  I'll underweight the odds of "YES" vis-a-vis the crowd.
When banks carry most of the oil, you bet your wallet they will pick it!
Updated: With Omicron virus and supplies in US improving, the probability is reduced from 90% to 80%

I've been wrong on this forecast as I've been too conservative on demand expectations and massively under appreciated supply discipline.  Due to the volatility of oil prices, I remain below consensus. 1. Capital Discipline with Strong Free Cash Flow: I'm now actively considering the negative impact of ESG focused investments on oil prices on the long-term supply dynamic for oil.  Oil demand is expected to increase at least through 2040, CEO's are being discouraged from incremental investment in oil and natural gas, and CEO's 
are shifting incremental cash flow toward clean energy sources.  As a result, this mean in lower supply, strong demand, and higher prices.  2. OPEC+ Micromanagement: Actually getting worse and not better.  They want to destroy the shale industry and become the marginal supply provider.   3. Iran Talks with the US have Staled: Continues to be staled within this timeframe.   4. Covid-19:  Getting better faster than I expected.   5. The US Dollar: Both the US dollar and oil prices have been moving higher. Historically, there is a rough negative correlation between the US dollar and oil prices. If the US dollar were start to depreciate, that would be positive for oil prices.
as we move closer in time - I see fewer reasons why it will drop by Dec 30th.

Surprised people are so confident in this with a lot of time to go, the volatility of the product, and the general negative forces acting on oil right now including press covering how high it currently is, OPEC possibly raising supply, winter months hurting demand, etc.  Still leaning yes but nowhere near 90%

Materially updating the probability based on the following dimensions: 1. Capital Discipline with Strong Free Cash Flow: This is the biggest surprise in my forecast - US shale producers are actually capital disciplined.  As a result, new production is surprisingly modest.     2. OPEC+ Micromanagement: No change.  I expect when prices are above $70 per barrel, OPEC+ will continue to increase oil supply.   3. Iran Talks with the US have Staled: There are news reports that China [https://www.reuters.com/business/exclusive-us-has-reached-out-china-about-cutting-oil-imports-iran-officials-say-2021-09-28/] is importing Iranian oil.  This means some of the Iranian supply is already in the market.  As a result, if a deal is reached, the new supply may negatively impact oil prices as much.  4. Covid-19: Given global progress on vaccinations, countries increasing learning to live with Covid-19, and the re-start of global travel, demand looks like it will resume. 5. The US Dollar: Both the US dollar and oil prices have been moving higher.  Historically, there is a rough negative correlation between the US dollar and oil prices.  If the US dollar were start to depreciate, that would be positive for oil prices.

The Brent crude price is approaching $80/barrel.  I had previously thought the price increases would reverse before yearend.  I now believe that I was wrong about that.  There are natural gas shortages in Europe.  See https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-09-27/europe-s-energy-crisis-is-about-to-go-global-as-gas-prices-soar?sref=x7nYEkiY.  Some oil may be substituted for gas to keep the lights on this winter. OPEC meets (virtually) next week, but I will bet against a significant increase in OPEC supply.  Russia and Saudi Arabia like the high price so long as US shale doesn't come back too strong.  So far it has not, and US production hasn't fully recovered from hurricane Ida.  Increasing the odds from 59% to 79%.

While I am not increasing my forecast, I wanted to provide an update to my thinking across five dimensions.   1. Capital Discipline with Strong Free Cash Flow:  After years of boom and bust cycles, it appears this time may be different in the near-term.  Large US shale oil and natural gas companies have shifted their focus to incorporate capital discipline.  Effectively, they are using their free cash flow from profitable wells to (A) return capital to shareholders and (B) pay down debt.  The first page of the PXD earnings presentation talks about paying an "Inaugural Variable Dividend" and throughout the EOG earnings presentation they reference paying down debt, returning capital to shareholders, and maintaining production (note: not increasing production). 2.  OPEC+ Micromanagement:  The body language out of the Saudi Arabia oil minister is that OPEC+ wants to keep the market slightly undersupplied through April 2022.  This means monitoring demand at a monthly frequency and adjusting production accordingly.  If the Delta variant persists and keeps demand from increasing, OPEC+ is likely to limit the amount of new production coming to the market.    3. Iran Talks with the US have Staled:  All indications that new supply from Iran coming to the market as a result of JCPOA negotiations is unlikely.   4. Covid-19:  This is the wildcard in my forecast for three of reasons (A) Vaccines are not approved for children under 12, (B) Global vaccination rates dramatically vary by country, and (C) New variants that further reduce vaccine efficacy.  From a demand modeling perspective, it is relatively easy to extrapolate current trends.  Further, if we have a significant increase in demand due to a waning of the pandemic demand will increase and OPEC+ will increase supply to avoid $80 per barrel oil prices or more.  OPEC+ does not want to incentivize US shale players to drill new wells.  At the same time, it is hard to model weaker-than-expected demand as this would imply a combination of a new variant, government lockdowns, and / or the unvaccinated becoming a large problem.  As a result, I see the demand skew (with respect to market expectations) with more downside risk. 5. The US Dollar:  A number of forecasters have indicated that the dollar may increase to decrease.  There are arguments for and against a change in the US dollar from real rate differentials, market positioning via futures, twin deficits in the US, relative monetary policy, etc.  From my perspective, the risk is fairly balanced in the next six months.  While I believe the US dollar should depreciate due to the large twin deficits (fiscal and trade), in the near-term a hawkish fed (i.e. starting a tapering program) and strong real growth from a consumer that has significant savings may keep the US dollar supported.  2022 may be the year of US dollar weakness as the world reopens from Covid-19. Sources:
1. EOG Q2'2021 Earnings Presentation: https://s24.q4cdn.com/589393778/files/doc_financials/2021/q2/EOG_0821.pdf
2. PXD Q2'2021 Earnings Presentation: https://investors.pxd.com/static-files/e33ef32a-6588-4a7d-aad9-9e5ba73c5a49
3. https://www.marketwatch.com/story/to-pause-or-not-to-pause-oil-output-increases-is-the-question-opec-faces-as-it-meets-wednesday-11630093332
4. https://www.cnbc.com/2021/08/03/iran-nuclear-deal-talks-are-stuck-after-substantial-progress-negotiator-says.html

Last time, I had discussed how the OPEC deal sent oil prices way higher. Since that happened, the oil markets have reversed, both due to OPEC deal going through as well as the rise of the Delta variant causing people to panic about oil demand. Overall, the US crude stockpiles are still going into their ninth week of declines, so the effect of the shortage may not be immediate. The current futures contract for December is $69, hovering very close to the 70 mark. Thus, I'm revising my forecast to lower the probability that oil is above 70 at end of year.

I am keeping my probability at 41% after additional research into supply, demand, and futures market pricing: 1. Supply:  Oil and OPEC+ have been surprisingly well disciplined.  While the forecast period still have 5+ months, and I'm skeptical production discipline remains into 2022, I have to acknowledge this surprise [https://www.naturalgasintel.com/eps-to-repeat-capital-discipline-mantra-in-2q-results-but-ofs-may-signal-price-increases/].  This discipline is a desire to avoid an oil price collapse by keeping supply tight.  With that said, OPEC+ still needs to resolve the dispute with the UAE around increasing their baseline.  While there are news stories that indicate a deal has been reached, it still needs to be approved by OPEC+.  If one country wants to increase production, should we not expect other countries to private encourage as well? 2. Demand:  Based on EIA and OPEC forecasts, demand into 2H'2021 and into 1H'2022 is expected to be near 2019 levels - around 100 mb/d.  I'm concerned this is too rosy, as it does not seem to consider the impact of new and existing Covid-19 variants around the world.  When schools and offices reopen in the fall and we move into the winter with at least 20% of the adult population in many developed economies choosing not to be vaccinated, it is not hard to foresee oil demand waning.  Put another way, I'm skeptical we will be back to pre-pandemic real activity levels.   3. Market Pricing [https://www.cmegroup.com/markets/energy/crude-oil/light-sweet-crude.quotes.html]: The December 2021 CME future price is currently $68.79.   As my prior is that oil prices are expectations of future supply and demand, and I am focusing my thinking around supply and demand for Q1'2022.  As a result, I am going to keep my probability at 41%.

Position here is based on social-meta, rather than data, delta variant should start coming under control over by Oct-Nov, which gives us a little lull around Christmas for the "west" and Christians to get optimistic.  This should compound with successful vaccine roll outs in some places, and as such an increase in demand of oil in the lead up to Christmas, in time for producers to ramp up production, slowing the impact of the upswing in demand.  Now if they don't, if the later does not happen the price goes up, but if the former doesn't happens the price comes down, then we will see more than a small dip in price again.

As noted by others, it looks like the UAE and Saudi Arabia are close to an agreement on the UAE's production quota. [See https://on.ft.com/3zbS1oL if you don't have subscription to FT.com; https://www.ft.com/content/5c1a3ee8-2630-48de-b386-976aa9d24040 if you do.] But even if the deal is agreed by all the OPEC+ nations it doesn't guarantee peace within the cartel.  Other producers could also demand larger shares of the total quota.  There is the possibility there could be a breakdown of internal discipline, with a resultant drop in crude prices.  I'll bet against that happening over the next 6 months, but not with a lot of conviction.  At 53% I'm only a little bit below the crowd's 62%.
Looks like a UAE / KSA deal is imminent; https://reut.rs/3eknxbX  @cafebedouin / @MCowley  / @SE_Meyer

The recently released International Energy Agency (IEA) July 2021 Report says economic growth will be hampered if OPEC+ doesn't come to an agreement to increase production.  See https://www.iea.org/reports/oil-market-report-july-2021.  The IEA report concludes "Oil markets are likely to remain volatile until there is clarity on OPEC+ production policy. And volatility does not help ensure orderly and secure energy transitions – nor is it in the interest of either producers or consumers." With nearly 6 months until the close of this question I will go (slightly) against the crowd, and put the odds at 61%, vs 66% for the crowd.
We are using more oil than we did as a planet and the expectation is that there will be less research and development due to political pressure.

OPEC members continue to struggle with coming to an agreement regarding increasing oil production. A meeting that was scheduled for 07/05 ended up being cancelled and there is no future meeting planned yet. Each country has different desires and a unanimous decision needs to made to end the stalemate. I estimate there being a 20% chance of OPEC deciding to increase oil production by December. Brent crude oil has been in a strong uptrend with no signs of reversal so far. Even if price comes off a bit, looks at historical prices $70 has been a strong area of demand so I would expect that area to hold. If no OPEC agreement has been made, I estimate there being an 90% chance of the price holding above $70.

Source: https://www.reuters.com/business/energy/us-shale-restraint-pushes-oil-prices-multi-year-high-kemp-2021-06-04/ Price is a function of supply and demand. We will treat each of these separately. In terms of supply, both OPEC+ and North American shale producers have expressed a desire to temper supply increases so as to allow oil price to continue drifting upward. On the other hand, demand for oil continues to grow as global economies recover from the coronavirus pandemic. OPEC forecasts that this recovery will take until the end of 2022. Brent prices has been trending upward steadily, essentially doubling in the eight months from November 2021 to now. Barring any drastic action on the parts of OPEC or North American producers, or another freak demand drop, Brent prices should finish above $70 at the end of 2021. We estimate a 15% total probability for these listed and unlisted failure cases.

A few weeks ago, I had a forecast slightly under that of everyone else, mainly due to concerns over whether the post-pandemic economy would recover fast enough for demand to outpace supply and continue the rally. In light of the OPEC+ deal that just fell through today implying that the quota limits would stay at least through August with potential easing afterwards at rates slower than market anticipation, the prices have shot up and Brent especially is seeing potential pricing of near $100. Thus, I revise my forecast to much higher than that of my peers, who may not have had a chance to react to this news outbreak yet. The main holdback from being 100% is again the surge of Delta variant cases, and potential price war should UAE decide not to compromise whatsoever with Russia and Saudi Arabia, who are both already in agreement.
Failure of OPEC to agree on production quotas makes it more likely for oil to exceed $70 per barrel on December 30.

Several new developments helped inform increasing my probability for 30% to 41%:
1. OPEC+ Meetings:  There is currently a stand-off within OPEC+ between Saudi Arabia and the UAE around the extension of managed production increases beyond April 2022 (https://www.theweek.in/news/world/2021/07/05/opec-meeting-collapses-without-deal-after-uae-saudi-arabia-clash.html).  It is not clear how much OPEC+ will increase production.
2. The group here has been increasing their forecast with a number referencing option or futures prices.  I may be under appreciating the production discipline of OPEC and energy firms. I am looking forward to reading the July EIA monthly report on July 7th and the OPEC monthly oil market report.

OPEC + doesn't seem to be able to reach agreement on the next stage of production quotas and no new OPEC + meeting has been scheduled thus creating an impasse and potential disruption of the current agreement and raising the possibility of a price war; https://bit.ly/3dKLxVA. However, a price war is not in the interests of any OPEC+ members and it's likely that today's meeting was cancelled so negotiations at a higher level can take place in closed rooms. In the meantime, market speculation has lead to higher prices today. Time will tell if KSA and the other OPEC+ members can persuade UAE to stay on board. 30 December is still a long way off and there's more than a 50:50 IMO that UAE can be brought into iine. That said, Delta variant Covid-19 could lead to further curtailment of demand.
@cafebedouin / @SE_Meyer / @MCowley

Did some research to find that according to Black-Scholes, N(d2) is the probability of the option being exercised. Looked at December 70 strike calls as my option of choice so N(d2) => probability it finishes ITM => probability of Brent Crude Oil finishing higher than $70. Used the following values pulled off Bloomberg around 11:30 ET on 7/2/2021 to get roughly 62%: S = 76.06
K = 70
r = 0.0148
sigma = 0.31327
T = 126/252
We can just look at the futures pricing to find that it is incredibly likely, since both the Jan 2022 and Dec 2021 Future are trading higher than $70.

Future trading at $70. Base rate 50%. Now adjusting for base rate. No signs of OPEC ramping production, Russia wont cause oil market problems as U.S. production has been hurt and a third of their government revenue comes from oil and gas, massive global energy demand, increased shipping costs and volume. Commodities have a much larger momentum factor in general than equities as well.

Currently, Brent Crude oil is trading at $75.61. However, the more important metric may be where the future is currently trading at. The Dec 2021 Future is $73.53 and the Jan 2022 Future is $72.87. These both imply that Brent crude oil will finish higher than $70 on December 30 2021. Additionally, the December 2021 Options for Crude oil are currently pricing a 30% implied volatility for this product. This makes me believe that Brent Crude oil is relatively likely to end above $70.00, however there is still a possibility about the price having changes over the next six months. Pricing a 70 call December option gives a delta of 0.64 so I think there is about a 64% chance to be valued at expiry. The value of the future for January is lower though so I priced that in slightly to get my estimate.
We can update my previous forecast to include new prices (https://www.barchart.com/futures/quotes/CBZ21/volatility-greeks/dec-21).

I used the annualized volatility to scale back to a volatility for Brent crude oil from Bloomberg and then attempted to simulate a random walk with for the change in price standard deviation set to the daily volatility. I attempted to also add some drift component due to mean reversion that equated to reverting back to the 1Y mean in expectation over the course of the time from now until December i.e. Y_{i+1} = Y_{i} + (long term mean - curr price)/number of days. The reason is that mean reversion is quite common for commodities such as Brent crude oil based on some research. The simulation yielded approximately a 65% chance of the cost per barrel to exceed $70.

Let's state some qualitative details. Brent futures price crude oil at about $75 per barrel. Oil dipped majorly since covid, and has steadily been climbing since the beginning of 2020. In the US, roughly 2/3 of oil consumption comes from transportation (https://www.eia.gov/energyexplained/oil-and-petroleum-products/use-of-oil.php). We might extrapolate that oil prices dipped because demand dropped as global transportation slowed during Covid. Statista documents how travel rates have dipped significantly (https://www.statista.com/statistics/564717/airline-industry-passenger-traffic-globally/). We may therefore expect them to surge as vaccination rates across the world rise, and travel returns to post-COVID levels.  I would do something fancy with yearly volatility and confidence intervals, but here I'm just going with the crowd at 80% likelihood. It seems relatively consistent with my qualitative reasoning, but this isn't really robust at all...

Similar to my peers, I took a look at the futures contracts for Brent. It seems that the nearer dated ones are more expensive, around 74 for August expiry, than the December ones, only 71. The future seems to suggest a slightly higher than 50% chance of Brent finishing above 70, but there are two other factors to consider. One is the recent gains that my peers pointed out, which is seemingly short lives as the pricing on different dated futures contracts would imply. The other factor for consideration is the possibility of OPEC+ actions. There have already been talks about increasing production, and despite the increased demand for oil due to a reopening economy, other figures such as Fed chair Powell have suggested these price increased are temporary. These two factors seem to suggest that oil prices may start to trend down soon. Thus, my prediction is a slightly lower than 50% chance that is currently being implied in the market (not too much lower since the market is already pricing some of this information in).

By using historical data and random sampling, it seems that my prediction is heavily varied on the historical time window that is selected (1 year historical prices vs 2 year vs 5 year) — using a longer look-back period implies a 50-50 chance of hitting higher than 70, while a short period is closer to 85% chance (it's important to note that the 1 year data is biased due to crude oil's recent gains — from Apr till June, the price has rebounded from 25 to 75). Given the potentially mean-reverting nature of Brent crude oil, I'm not very confident right now but am leaning towards Yes. I will update by prediction weekly based on running more simulations + analyst predictions.

I used bootstrapping on the percent change of the closing price. Only using data from the last 200 days gave me a 92% chance of finishing higher than 70 because of the bullrun that happened in this period. However using data from the last 2years, 3year, 4years gave me very similar probabilities between 55 to 60%. I will try to update this everyday based on the new close. I did not make any direction assumptions here but only considered the volatility of this price

We proceed by examining the delta of the Brent crude oil 70 call with expiry at 30 December 2021. We use the data at https://www.barchart.com/futures/quotes/CBZ21/options/dec-21 and the options calculator at https://www.optionseducation.org/toolsoptionquotes/optionscalculator. We have the following inputs: stock price = 70.14, strike price = 70, implied volatility = 31.7%, risk free interest rate is 1.45%. The calculator then tells us that the delta is 0.552. This delta is roughly the partial derivative of the call price with respect to the price of the underlying. Some people consider the delta to be a good approximation of the probability the call finishes in the money, i.e. here the probability that crude oil is at least $70 per barrel. The high-level idea is that a $1 increase in the underlying will result in a $1 * p increase in the value of the option, where p is the probability of finishing in the money, because the option needs to finish in the money to "enjoy" or "receive" that dollar increase. Since the delta is calculated to be 0.55, we estimate this probability at 55%. A better approach might be to look at deltas over time (especially since these calculations were on a Monday and might reflect some weekend idiosyncrasies). Nevertheless, I think deferring to the quant analysts who have money on the line is an okay approximation here.

This could be viewed as a classic supply vs. demand debate.  However, in my view asset markets, such as the price of Brent crude oil, are typically based on forward expectations of supply and demand with about a 6-month implicit forward view. So from my perspective, the way to answer this question is to try to ascertain expectations for oil supply and demand in Q1 and Q2’2022. The EIA is a source of oil supply and demand forecasts through 2021 and into 2022. (https://www.eia.gov/outlooks/steo/data/browser/#/?v=6&f=Q&s=&start=201701&end=202204&ctype=linechart&maptype=0&id=&linechart=PAPR_OECD)  According to the EIA and using quarterly data: *My apologies for the table below.  The format is poor and I'm trying to refine it. 	                     Q2’2021	Q3’2021	Q4’2021	Q1’2022	Q2’2022	Q4’2019 (Reference Rate)
Total Production	95.33	99.08	100.10	100.03	101.70	101.70
Total Demand	96.86	98.96	100.27	99.86	101.01	101.41
Difference	         -1.53	   0.12	    -0.17	   0.17	0.69	0.30

Total Stock Draw	  1.53	-0.12	0.17	-0.17	-0.69	-0.30 Effectively into early 2022, supply and demand is expected to be in equilibrium with over supply in Q2’2022. Further, there are several other factors to consider:
Oil Supply: The longer oil prices remain above $50, production for US shale may increase.  For context, US oil production reached 20.20 million barrels in Q4’2019 and it is not projected to reach that level until at least Q4’2022 (at 20.40).  If US shale producers increase rig counts combined with their increased productivity per well, US supply could surprise to the upside.  If oil supply surprises the upside, prices will be pressed downward. Oil Demand:  Global reopening through increased covid-19 vaccinations could surprise to the upside and I could see oil prices increases in the next 3-months.  If the reopening is stronger than expected, this would be a reason I underestimate the probability.   What to Watch:
- US Shale Production - both the number of oil rigs and oil production:  For context, the cost to extract oil from US shale reserves is generally less than $50 per barrell
- OPEC+ Production and Upcoming Meetings
- US - Iran Negotiations
- Mideast & Geopolitics Areas I'm Downplaying Due to the Time Horizon:
- ESG and Climate Change are long-term impacts on oil prices, and they may actually be positive for oil prices before they are negative due to lower Capex.  It will take a long time for economies to shift away from fossil fuels so demand will be fairly consistent.  If Capex were to fall (i.e. new well being drilled), supply may be constrained, which could actually increase oil prices. Given that the models expect oil supply and demand to be in equilibrium at the end of 2021 with oversupply into early 2022, I estimate the a 30% probability that Brent oil prices will be above $70 on 30 December 2021.  The higher uncertainty is a result of the range of outcomes due to demand associated with the reopening trade.

There's a saying in the oil business -- "the cure for high prices is high prices, and the cure for low prices is low prices."  High prices have the effect of pulling oil out of the ground.  At $70+ per barrel US shale could produce more, Iranian oil output could increase, or the Saudis and Russians could increase output to keep a lid on prices. Recently in the press there have been stories of a new super cycle in commodity prices.  See https://on.ft.com/3feuDyb.  But another article in the FT explains that there is a great deal of uncertainty around both supply and demand for oil.  See https://on.ft.com/3xMJmIH. So I believe with a 91% probability the crowd is too certain the answer is "YES."  Since I don't know what will happen, I'll start with a guess of 50%.
